name: Pakkhús Restaurant - Höfn's Langoustine Capital Seafood
description: Pakkhús Restaurant occupies a prime harborside location in Höfn, southeast Iceland's lobster capital where local fishing boats land some of the world's finest langoustines (Nephrops norvegicus, marketed internationally as "Iceland lobster" though technically a large prawn species), creating direct supply chain from boat to kitchen that ensures exceptional freshness and quality while supporting the fishing industry that sustains Höfn's 2,200 residents and defines the town's economy and identity. The restaurant's name "Pakkhús" means "warehouse" in Icelandic, referencing both the building's historical use as harbor storage facility and the restaurant's current role as repository for the region's exceptional seafood bounty. Operating daily 12:00 PM to 10:00 PM when open (note: the restaurant was temporarily closed in late 2025 with planned February 2026 reopening, so visitors should verify current status before making special trips), Pakkhús serves lunch and dinner to tourists driving the Ring Road and locals celebrating special occasions or hosting visiting friends and family. The menu showcases langoustines prepared multiple ways that highlight the sweet.
